ticket.title: Destroy should respect optimistic locking
ticket.original-body:
Optimistic locking doesn't currently affect #destroy calls. This is causing me problems because my after_destroy handlers can end up using stale data. I could also see it causing trouble if a model had some sort of 'do_not_delete' flag that was changed right after AR loaded the record.
So, it seems to me that #destroy should follow the same optimistic locking logic as updates do. That is, add the current lock version to the WHERE clause and raise a StaleObjectError if the delete fails.
I've written a patch (with a test and updated documentation) that accomplishes this.
ticket.latest-body:
Optimistic locking doesn't currently affect #destroy calls. This is causing me problems because my after_destroy handlers can end up using stale data. I could also see it causing trouble if a model had some sort of 'do_not_delete' flag that was changed right after AR loaded the record.
So, it seems to me that #destroy should follow the same optimistic locking logic as updates do. That is, add the current lock version to the WHERE clause and raise a StaleObjectError if the delete fails.
I've written a patch (with a test and updated documentation) that accomplishes this.
ticket.original-body-html:
Optimistic locking doesn't currently affect #destroy calls. This is causing me problems because my after_destroy handlers can end up using stale data. I could also see it causing trouble if a model had some sort of 'do_not_delete' flag that was changed right after AR loaded the record.

So, it seems to me that #destroy should follow the same optimistic locking logic as updates do. That is, add the current lock version to the WHERE clause and raise a StaleObjectError if the delete fails.

I've written a patch (with a test and updated documentation) that accomplishes this.

version.body:
Optimistic locking doesn't currently affect #destroy calls. This is causing me problems because my after_destroy handlers can end up using stale data. I could also see it causing trouble if a model had some sort of 'do_not_delete' flag that was changed right after AR loaded the record.
So, it seems to me that #destroy should follow the same optimistic locking logic as updates do. That is, add the current lock version to the WHERE clause and raise a StaleObjectError if the delete fails.
I've written a patch (with a test and updated documentation) that accomplishes this.
version.body-html:
Optimistic locking doesn't currently affect #destroy calls. This is causing me problems because my after_destroy handlers can end up using stale data. I could also see it causing trouble if a model had some sort of 'do_not_delete' flag that was changed right after AR loaded the record.

So, it seems to me that #destroy should follow the same optimistic locking logic as updates do. That is, add the current lock version to the WHERE clause and raise a StaleObjectError if the delete fails.

I've written a patch (with a test and updated documentation) that accomplishes this.
version.title: [patch] Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.body: I think it's a solid patch. I'm surprised it wasn't there before. The logic is straightforward, the tests and docs are clear. I recommend it :-)
version.body-html: I think it's a solid patch. I'm surprised it wasn't there before. The logic is straightforward, the tests and docs are clear. I recommend it :-)
version.title: [patch] Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.body:
(from [0d922885fb54c19f04680482f024452859218910]) Ensure Model#destroy respects optimistic locking [#1966 state:resolved]
Signed-off-by: Pratik Naik <pratiknaik@gmail.com> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/0d922885fb54c19f04680482f024452859218910
version.body-html:
(from [0d922885fb54c19f04680482f024452859218910]) Ensure Model#destroy respects optimistic locking [#1966 state:resolved]

Signed-off-by: Pratik Naik pratiknaik@gmail.com http://github.com/rails/rails/co...
version.title: Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.body: This is giving me pain in conjunction with :dependent => :destroy and counter caching. parent.destroy will always fail if it has a counter cache any dependent objects. When a dependent child object is destroyed, its parent's counter cache is decremented AND its lock version is updated. Then the parent destroy is attempted, but the lock version no longer matches.
version.body-html:
This is giving me pain in conjunction with :dependent => :destroy and counter caching. parent.destroy will always fail if it has a counter cache any dependent objects.

When a dependent child object is destroyed, its parent's counter cache is decremented AND its lock version is updated. Then the parent destroy is attempted, but the lock version no longer matches.
version.title: Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.body: What we really want here is to check the lock_version but with READ_COMMITTED transaction isolation. We don't care if the current transaction has bumped the lock, only if others have.
version.body-html: What we really want here is to check the lock_version but with READ_COMMITTED transaction isolation. We don't care if the current transaction has bumped the lock, only if others have.
version.title: Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.title: Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.body:
How about just not updating the counters during a destroy? If the parent is going to be destroyed anyway, it doesn't seem like it does much good to the counter of its children as each individual one is destroyed. That should make the destroy go a bit faster and prevent the stale object exceptions.
I've updated my patch to have the parent redefine the before_destroy counter_cache callback on its children to just an empty method before destroying them (and it should apply cleanly against master now).
Let me know what you think.
version.body-html:
How about just not updating the counters during a destroy? If the parent is going to be destroyed anyway, it doesn't seem like it does much good to the counter of its children as each individual one is destroyed. That should make the destroy go a bit faster and prevent the stale object exceptions.

I've updated my patch to have the parent redefine the before_destroy counter_cache callback on its children to just an empty method before destroying them (and it should apply cleanly against master now).

Let me know what you think.
version.title: Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.body:
Updated the patch to include better error messages as suggested by schorsch: http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/0d922885fb54c19f04680482f024452859218910
Also, I didn't mention it in the last post, but this patch does include unit tests to make sure that the parent.destroy scenario works without any problems.
version.body-html:
Updated the patch to include better error messages as suggested by schorsch: http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/0d922885fb54c19f04680482f02445...

Also, I didn't mention it in the last post, but this patch does include unit tests to make sure that the parent.destroy scenario works without any problems.
version.title: Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.body: Just realized that I hadn't correctly formatted the patch...
version.body-html: Just realized that I hadn't correctly formatted the patch...
version.title: Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.body: +1, I tested Curtis's optimistic-destroy4.diff against the latest master, works great. This is also an important bug to fix, IMHO.
version.body-html: +1, I tested Curtis's optimistic-destroy4.diff against the latest master, works great. This is also an important bug to fix, IMHO.
version.title: Destroy should respect optimistic locking

version.body:
(from [ce5af2fefe0e447669fa8b7031f07558bfc84f4a]) Destroy respects optimistic locking.
Now works with :dependent => :destroy and includes unit tests for that case. Also includes better error messages when updating/deleting stale objects.
[#1966 state:committed]
Signed-off-by: Jeremy Kemper <jeremy@bitsweat.net> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/ce5af2fefe0e447669fa8b7031f07558bfc84f4a
version.body-html:
(from [ce5af2fefe0e447669fa8b7031f07558bfc84f4a]) Destroy respects optimistic locking.

Now works with :dependent => :destroy and includes unit tests for that
case. Also includes better error messages when updating/deleting stale
objects.

[#1966 state:committed]

Signed-off-by: Jeremy Kemper jeremy@bitsweat.net
http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/ce5af2fefe0e447669fa8b7031f075...
